metadata.title: California Water Infrastructure Funding Programs
metadata.description: Machine-readable catalog of federal, state, and private funding programs for water infrastructure projects
metadata.disclaimer: Eligibility information is for guidance only. Always verify current requirements directly with the administering agency before applying.

programs.name: Army Corps of Engineers Section 219 Environmental Infrastructure
programs.description: Assists public entities with water-related environmental infrastructure including wastewater treatment, water supply and storage, recycled water systems, and well construction.

fundingRange.notes: Standard: 75% federal / 25% local; WRDA 2024 enhancement: up to 90% for certain projects

additionalCriteria: Must be in authorized geographic area
Publicly owned infrastructure
Funding only through annual appropriation bills
Sponsor provides all lands, easements, rights-of-way

programs.ragQuery: How does the Army Corps Section 219 program fund water environmental infrastructure projects?

programs.name: Building Resilient Infrastructure and Communities
programs.description: Pre-disaster competitive program for resilience projects. CAUTION: Program terminated April 2025; currently in legal limbo with no new funding cycles announced as of January 2026.

fundingRange.notes: SUSPENDED — $5B+ distributed prior to termination; ~$870M CA projects at risk; FY 2024 NOFO ($750M) canceled

additionalCriteria: PROGRAM CURRENTLY SUSPENDED — terminated April 2025
Federal court temporarily halted fund reallocation (Aug 2025)
Small/impoverished: 90% federal / 10% local

programs.ragQuery: What is the current status of the FEMA BRIC program for water infrastructure resilience?

programs.name: Clean Water Act Section 319 Nonpoint Source Grants
programs.administeredBy: State Water Resources Control Board (pass-through from EPA)
programs.description: Federal grants funding projects to reduce nonpoint source pollution from agricultural operations, forestry, urban stormwater, and other diffuse sources.

fundingRange.notes: Implementation: $250K-$1M; Planning: $50K-$250K; ~$3-4M annually for California

additionalCriteria: 25% non-federal match (waiver for DACs)
Must address priority watersheds identified by Regional Water Boards
Nine-element watershed-based plan required

programs.ragQuery: How do Clean Water Act Section 319 grants work for nonpoint source pollution projects in California?

programs.name: Community Development Block Grant
programs.administeredBy: HUD (CA Housing and Community Development for state program)
programs.description: Annual formula grants for community development including water and sewer infrastructure in communities serving low- and moderate-income populations.

fundingRange.notes: Formula-based allocation; 70% must benefit low/moderate-income persons

additionalCriteria: Must meet national objective: benefit low/moderate income, eliminate blight, or address urgent need
Entitlement communities: ≥50K population cities or ≥200K counties
State program: smaller non-entitlement communities

programs.ragQuery: How can communities use CDBG funding for water and sewer infrastructure projects?

programs.name: EDA Public Works Program
programs.description: Grants helping distressed communities upgrade water and sewer infrastructure for economic development, job creation, and private investment attraction.

fundingRange.notes: Recent CA example: $2.4M to City of Moreno Valley (drainage expansion); West Coast disaster allocation: $93.81M

additionalCriteria: Must demonstrate job creation/retention potential
Alignment with EDA investment priorities
Distressed community status

programs.ragQuery: How can distressed communities access EDA Public Works grants for water infrastructure?

programs.name: EPA Brownfields Grants
programs.description: Grants for assessment, cleanup, and remediation of contaminated properties including groundwater contamination requiring remediation for beneficial reuse.

fundingRange.notes: Cleanup grants: $500K-$4M; Assessment grants also available; CA FY 2025: $10.45M to 9 recipients

additionalCriteria: Submit through Grants.gov
Includes assessment, cleanup, and revolving loan fund categories

programs.ragQuery: What EPA Brownfields funding is available for groundwater contamination cleanup?

programs.name: EPA Environmental Justice Small Grants Program
programs.description: Community-based grants supporting environmental justice solutions including water quality, public health, and community education projects. Operating since 1994 with over $37M awarded.

fundingRange.notes: Up to $100,000 per project; FY 2025 limited to federally recognized tribal governments

additionalCriteria: FY 2025: Limited to federally recognized tribal governments
Previous cycles included CBOs and nonprofits

programs.ragQuery: What EPA environmental justice grants are available for water-related community projects?

programs.name: Flood Mitigation Assistance
programs.description: Annual competitive program funded through NFIP specifically targeting flood risk reduction for insured structures, including water facility elevation, acquisition, and floodproofing.

fundingRange.notes: FY 2024: $600M; FY 2023: $800M; demand ~$8B vs combined BRIC/FMA availability

additionalCriteria: NFIP participation required
NFIP policy must be in effect at application
Does NOT require disaster declaration
Repetitive loss: up to 90% federal; severe repetitive loss: up to 100%

programs.ragQuery: How does the FEMA Flood Mitigation Assistance program work for water infrastructure flood protection?

programs.name: Hazard Mitigation Grant Program
programs.description: Post-disaster grants for hazard mitigation projects including water infrastructure resilience improvements such as seismic retrofitting, backup power, flood protection, and drought mitigation.

fundingRange.notes: Formula-based (post-disaster); 88% construction, 7% planning, 5% innovative/pilot

additionalCriteria: Requires presidential disaster declaration
Applications due within 1 year of declaration
Project must be in FEMA-approved local hazard mitigation plan
Benefit-cost ratio ≥1.0 required
Small/impoverished: 90% federal / 10% local

programs.ragQuery: How can water utilities access FEMA Hazard Mitigation Grant Program funding after disasters?

programs.name: Special Evaluation Assistance for Rural Communities and Households
programs.description: Predevelopment grants for very small rural communities to cover feasibility studies, preliminary design, and technical assistance needed before applying for construction financing.

fundingRange.notes: $60,000 or 75% of predevelopment costs (whichever is lower)

additionalCriteria: Population ≤2,500 (more restrictive than standard USDA programs)
MHI below poverty line or <80% statewide non-metropolitan MHI
Cannot pay for already-completed work

programs.ragQuery: What is the USDA SEARCH grant program for very small rural community predevelopment planning?

programs.name: Title XVI Water Reclamation and Reuse Program
programs.description: Sole federal authority for water recycling/reuse in western states, providing cost-share funding for municipal, industrial, and agricultural wastewater reuse. California has 41 authorized projects.

fundingRange.notes: $20M or 25% of total cost (whichever less); ~$20M annual funding; demand exceeds supply by >$700M

additionalCriteria: 75% non-federal cost share required
Completed Feasibility Study reviewed by Reclamation required
Findings must be transmitted to Congress for eligibility

programs.ragQuery: How does the Title XVI federal water recycling program work and what are the requirements?

programs.name: USDA Emergency Community Water Assistance Grants
programs.description: Rapid response grant funding for rural communities experiencing acute water emergencies from drought, flood, contamination, or equipment failure. No federal disaster declaration required.

fundingRange.notes: Emergency repairs/transmission lines: $150K max; Water source infrastructure: $1M max

additionalCriteria: Federal disaster declaration NOT required
Major decline in water quality/quantity within 2 years
MHI below state non-metropolitan MHI
Year-round applications

programs.ragQuery: How can rural communities access USDA emergency water assistance grants without a federal disaster declaration?

programs.name: USDA Water and Waste Disposal Loan and Grant Program
programs.description: Primary federal financing mechanism for rural water and sanitation projects, providing long-term low-interest loans combined with grants to communities that cannot obtain adequate credit through conventional channels.

fundingRange.notes: No stated cap — based on need and fund availability; combines loans with grants when funds available

additionalCriteria: Rural areas and towns with 10,000 or fewer residents
Must demonstrate inability to obtain credit elsewhere
Colonias established before Oct 1, 1989 eligible

programs.ragQuery: What USDA rural water programs are available for small communities and what are the eligibility requirements?

programs.name: USDA Water and Waste Facility Loans/Grants for Colonias
programs.description: Addresses water and waste infrastructure needs of colonias -- unincorporated communities established before October 1, 1989 with inadequate infrastructure and low-income populations.

fundingRange.notes: 100% grants possible under certain circumstances; matching usually required

interestRate.notes: Same tiered rates as standard USDA water programs

additionalCriteria: Colonias established before October 1, 1989
Significant health risks from inadequate water/waste services
Rural areas ≤10,000 population

programs.ragQuery: What special USDA funding is available for colonias with inadequate water infrastructure?

programs.name: Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act
programs.description: Federal credit assistance for large water infrastructure projects too large or complex for traditional state revolving fund programs, with $6.5B available and capacity to support $14B in total projects.

fundingRange.notes: $20M minimum for large communities; $5M minimum for small communities (≤25,000); max 49% of eligible costs; $6.5B program capacity

interestRate.notes: Equal to or exceeding U.S. Treasury rate for similar maturity; locked at closing; one-time reset available if rates decline

additionalCriteria: Total federal assistance cannot exceed 80%
15% set aside for small community projects
Letter of Interest required
Up to 5 years principal deferral

programs.ragQuery: What are the WIFIA loan program requirements for large water infrastructure projects?

programs.name: WaterSMART Drought Response Program
programs.description: Drought resiliency and small storage projects addressing water treatment improvements, infrastructure, and water management tools for drought preparedness.

fundingRange.notes: Recent investment: $33.5M for 14 projects across western states

additionalCriteria: Includes drought resiliency and small storage components
Competitive through Grants.gov

programs.ragQuery: What Bureau of Reclamation drought response funding is available for water infrastructure resilience?

programs.name: WaterSMART Planning and Project Design Grants
programs.description: Cost-sharing grants for site-specific final design of medium and large-scale water projects, integrating water strategy grants, project design grants, and drought contingency planning.

fundingRange.notes: 50% federal cost share; results in ~60% design package

additionalCriteria: General planning work must be completed
Preliminary studies identifying specific location required
Includes water strategy, project design, and drought contingency planning

programs.ragQuery: What Bureau of Reclamation planning and design grants help water agencies develop projects?

programs.name: WaterSMART Small-Scale Water Efficiency Projects
programs.description: Smaller focused efficiency improvements including flow measurement, automation systems, canal lining, and defined infrastructure improvements identified through planning.

fundingRange.notes: 50% federal cost share; FY24-25 estimated $12M total; recent cycle: 36 projects for $3.3M

additionalCriteria: 50% non-federal cost share
Must be identified through prior planning

programs.ragQuery: What WaterSMART small-scale efficiency grants are available for irrigation and water delivery improvements?

programs.name: WaterSMART Water and Energy Efficiency Grants
programs.description: Competitive cost-share grants for water conservation, efficiency improvements, and supply reliability projects in western states, leveraging $3.86B in federal investment with $9.2B non-federal.

fundingRange.notes: 50% federal cost share; FY 2025 allocation ~$90M for all WaterSMART programs

additionalCriteria: 50% non-federal cost share required
Entities with water or power delivery authority
Project must complete within 2-3 years

programs.ragQuery: What Bureau of Reclamation WaterSMART grants are available for water efficiency and conservation?

programs.name: California Community Foundation Safe Clean Water Grants
programs.description: Partnership with Water Foundation for LA County stormwater education and engagement, supporting climate adaptation, environmental justice, and equitable disaster response.

fundingRange.notes: $8.5M available for Safe, Clean Water grants program

additionalCriteria: 501(c)(3) nonprofits (not private foundations)
Located within and primarily serving LA County
Online interactive eligibility test required

programs.ragQuery: What California Community Foundation grants support water and stormwater projects in Los Angeles County?

programs.name: David and Lucile Packard Foundation
programs.description: Major philanthropic foundation with California Communities Initiative focusing on clean water access in six Central Coast/Bay Area counties, plus ocean conservation programs.

fundingRange.notes: Open calls: $50K-$200K typically; larger institutional grants available; 12-month terms

additionalCriteria: Geographic focus: Fresno, Monterey, San Benito, San Mateo, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz counties
Cannot provide grants to individuals
Actively encourages BIPOC-led organizations

programs.ragQuery: What Packard Foundation grants are available for California water and conservation projects?

programs.name: Environmental Impact Bonds
programs.description: Innovative financing linking investor returns to environmental outcomes, where private investors provide upfront capital for water infrastructure and compensation is indexed to realized environmental benefits.

fundingRange.notes: DC Water model: $25M bond; variable based on project; requires investor-grade outcome quantification

interestRate.notes: Performance-based — rate can be predetermined or indexed to environmental outcomes

additionalCriteria: Requires quantifiable environmental outcomes with investor-grade precision
Needs clear performance metrics and monitoring protocols
Best for green infrastructure with performance uncertainty

programs.ragQuery: How do Environmental Impact Bonds work for water infrastructure and green infrastructure projects?

programs.name: Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation
programs.description: Environmental Conservation Program supporting clean water advocacy, research, and education, with healthy oceans and open lands programs. Does not accept unsolicited proposals.

fundingRange.notes: Annual grantmaking: $5-12M; typical $2K-$500K; average ~$10K; grants >$1M rare

additionalCriteria: Does NOT accept unsolicited proposals
No direct avenue for getting in touch
Focus on conservation and environmental innovation

programs.ragQuery: What does the Moore Foundation fund for water conservation and environmental protection?

programs.name: Green Bonds for Water Infrastructure
programs.administeredBy: Various issuers (e.g., San Francisco PUC, state agencies)
programs.description: Fixed-income securities with proceeds earmarked for environmentally beneficial water projects, verified under Climate Bonds Standard. SF PUC has issued $3.7B+ in certified green bonds.

fundingRange.notes: SF PUC July 2024: ~$1B issuance; varies by issuer; state bonds through voter-approved propositions

interestRate.notes: Market rates for tax-exempt or taxable municipal bonds; typically competitive due to green premium

additionalCriteria: Four core components: use of proceeds, project evaluation, management of proceeds, reporting
Climate Bonds Standard certification available
Applicable for large capital projects with environmental focus

programs.ragQuery: How can water agencies use green bonds to finance water infrastructure and environmental projects?

programs.name: NFWF Five Star Wetland and Urban Waters Restoration Program
programs.administeredBy: National Fish and Wildlife Foundation (with EPA and USDA)
programs.description: Competitive grants for wetland restoration, riparian habitat, coastal restoration, stormwater management, and community stewardship with 1:1 matching requirement.

fundingRange.notes: Annual funding ~$2.6M; average award $35K; range $20K-$50K; 12-18 month duration

additionalCriteria: 1:1 match (non-federal, can include in-kind)
Must address all 5 priorities: habitat restoration, education, partnerships, measurable results, sustainability
Academic institutions also eligible

programs.ragQuery: What NFWF Five Star grants are available for wetland restoration and urban water projects?

programs.name: Pisces Foundation Urban Water Program
programs.description: Advances integrated One Water urban water strategy through grants supporting equitable water management, green stormwater infrastructure, and community-based solutions in major cities.

fundingRange.notes: $95K-$125K per year typical; multi-year (1-3 years); $6M+ invested since 2014

additionalCriteria: US-based 501(c)(3) public charities
City/county population at least 200,000
Must include grassroots community-based organization involvement
Concept note (1,000 words max) via email to water@piscesfoundation.org

programs.ragQuery: What Pisces Foundation One Water grants support urban water equity and green infrastructure?

programs.name: Resources Legacy Fund
programs.description: Environmental progress through trusted partnerships and creative campaigns, contributing to over $30B in public funding for climate, water, and nature including California's climate bonds.

fundingRange.notes: 2023 program expenses ~$35.4M; hundreds of grants annually; strategic partnerships, not open applications

additionalCriteria: Strategic partnerships rather than open applications
Fiscal sponsorship available for high-impact projects
Focus: climate, biodiversity, social equity

programs.ragQuery: What does Resources Legacy Fund support for California water and environmental policy?

programs.name: Spring Point Partners Delta Program
programs.description: Equity-centered water leadership program improving access to safe and affordable water by expanding diverse community representation in utility leadership and workforce development.

fundingRange.notes: Grant funding, impact investment, and capacity building; invitation only

additionalCriteria: Does NOT accept unsolicited proposals
Actively seeks compatible partners
Focus on utility leadership transformation and workforce equity

programs.ragQuery: What does Spring Point Partners fund for water utility leadership and workforce development?

programs.name: Water Foundation
programs.description: The only US intermediary foundation solely focused on water issues, with 284 California grants totaling $17M (2020-2024) supporting drinking water access, groundwater sustainability, equity, and policy advocacy.

fundingRange.notes: 284 CA grants totaling $17M (2020-2024); total national: ~$43M to 210+ organizations; invitation only

additionalCriteria: Does NOT accept unsolicited proposals
Organizations identified and invited by staff or partner networks
California is most substantially funded region (~71% of western grantmaking)

programs.ragQuery: What does the Water Foundation fund for California water policy, equity, and sustainability?

programs.name: William and Flora Hewlett Foundation
programs.description: Major foundation ($13.9B assets) with Western Conservation Strategy protecting natural resources and Climate Initiative supporting clean energy transition, including significant Klamath River restoration support.

fundingRange.notes: Most common: $50K-$750K; range from $10K to nearly $20M

additionalCriteria: Letters of Inquiry accepted for Climate and Energy program
Western Conservation Strategy focuses on western US and Canada

programs.ragQuery: What Hewlett Foundation grants support water conservation and climate resilience in California?

programs.name: DWSRF Emerging Contaminants Funding
programs.description: Federal Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act funding for treatment of PFAS and other emerging contaminants in drinking water, with 100% principal forgiveness for disadvantaged communities.

fundingRange.notes: $25M per water system maximum; no limit for DAC systems serving <25,000; California allocation $700M+

additionalCriteria: Must address emerging contaminants (PFAS, etc.)
Non-DAC systems >25,000 population: up to 50% as forgivable loans, $25M max

principalForgiveness.conditions: DAC communities: up to 100% of costs, no repayment; Non-DAC >25,000: up to 50%, $25M max

programs.ragQuery: What funding is available for PFAS and emerging contaminant treatment in drinking water systems?

programs.name: Integrated Regional Water Management Grant Program
programs.description: California's primary collaborative approach to regional water management, providing funding for implementation projects that support coordinated regional water management across 48 accepted IRWM regions.

fundingRange.notes: Prop 1: $510M ($403M awarded); Prop 4: $100M (new funding starting FY 2027-28); historical total $2B+

additionalCriteria: Must be in adopted IRWM Plan consistent with 2016 standards
Regional Water Management Group must submit
Match waived for DAC implementation projects
10% set-aside per Funding Area for DAC projects

programs.ragQuery: How does the IRWM grant program work and what are the regional requirements for funding?

programs.name: Proposition 1 Clean Safe Reliable Drinking Water
programs.description: Chapter 5 of Proposition 1 (2014 Water Bond) providing $520M for drinking water treatment facilities, distribution systems, source capacity, and contaminated water remediation.

fundingRange.notes: $520M authorized; $508.5M committed; 99.7% of Prop 1 funds committed overall

additionalCriteria: Match reduced or waived for DAC (MHI <80%)
Full grants for SDAC (MHI <60%)
Implementation phase — no new solicitations

programs.ragQuery: What Proposition 1 drinking water funding is still available for water infrastructure projects?

programs.name: Proposition 1 Groundwater Grant Program
programs.description: Provided $670M for groundwater contamination prevention and cleanup affecting drinking water supplies. Program is now closed with all funding committed.

fundingRange.notes: $670M authorized; CLOSED — all funding committed as of September 2025

additionalCriteria: CLOSED — no new applications
SDAC drinking water projects continue through DWSRF/CWSRF

programs.ragQuery: What happened to Proposition 1 groundwater cleanup funding and are there alternatives?

programs.name: Proposition 1 Storm Water Grant Program
programs.description: Provided $200M for multi-benefit stormwater projects including green infrastructure, rainwater/stormwater capture, treatment, and groundwater recharge.

fundingRange.notes: $200M total; 25 planning projects ($10M), 44 implementation projects ($180M); funding largely committed

additionalCriteria: Multi-benefit projects preferred (habitat, groundwater recharge, recreation)
Stormwater management cap: $20M for SFY 2025-26 through CWSRF

programs.ragQuery: What stormwater and green infrastructure grant programs are available through Proposition 1?

programs.name: Proposition 1 Water Recycling
programs.description: Chapter 9 of Proposition 1 providing $725M for water recycling treatment, storage, distribution, and groundwater recharge projects.

fundingRange.notes: $725M authorized; $706.4M committed; administered through WRFP

additionalCriteria: Grants cover 35% of reasonable construction cost
Match reduced for disadvantaged communities

programs.ragQuery: What Proposition 1 water recycling grants are available for recycled water projects?

programs.name: Proposition 4 Water Security Funding
programs.description: 2024 Climate Bond providing approximately $1.07 billion for safe drinking water, drought resilience, flood protection, and water resilience, including $100M for IRWM and $180M for SAFER.

fundingRange.notes: ~$1.07B for water security; $100M IRWM; $180M water/wastewater; implementation begins Fall 2025

additionalCriteria: New solicitations expected starting Fall 2025

programs.ragQuery: What water funding is available through California's Proposition 4 climate bond?

programs.name: Proposition 68 Water and Parks Bond
programs.description: 2018 California Drought, Water, Parks, Climate Bond providing $4.058 billion including water quality, supply, and infrastructure components with strong equity set-asides for disadvantaged communities.

fundingRange.notes: $4.058B total; includes $72M water recycling, $74M groundwater treatment ($16M SDAC set-aside)

additionalCriteria: Concept proposal then invited full application process
Preference for projects with matching funding

programs.ragQuery: What Proposition 68 water infrastructure funding is available for California communities?

programs.name: Small Community Drought Relief Program
programs.description: Provides $305 million for drought relief to communities not served by urban water suppliers, funding both temporary interim solutions and long-term infrastructure improvements.

fundingRange.notes: $305M total: $200M substantive relief, $20M household water tanks, $5M county drought planning

additionalCriteria: Communities NOT served by urban water suppliers (>3,000 customers or >3,000 AFY)
First-come, first-served (no competition)

programs.ragQuery: What drought relief funding is available for small rural communities not served by urban water suppliers?

programs.name: Small Community Wastewater Grant Fund
programs.description: Proposition 1 funded grants for small disadvantaged communities needing wastewater treatment, sewer improvements, septic-to-sewer conversions, and regionalization projects.

fundingRange.notes: $260M from Proposition 1; annual appropriation $8M; administered through CWSRF

additionalCriteria: Population <20,000
Disadvantaged community status prioritized

programs.ragQuery: What wastewater grants are available for small communities under 20,000 population?

programs.name: Urban and Multibenefit Drought Relief Program
programs.description: Provides drought relief funding for urban and regional water systems including emergency interties, well drilling, recycled water, and drought resiliency planning with DAC/tribal set-asides.

fundingRange.notes: 2022 round: ~$285M ($85M DAC/Tribal set-aside); 2021 round: ~$190M ($50M DAC set-aside)

additionalCriteria: Competitive during specified windows
DAC/underrepresented communities exempt from match

programs.ragQuery: What urban drought relief funding is available for regional water systems and cities?

programs.name: Urgent Drinking Water Needs Program
programs.description: California's primary mechanism for immediate interim water supplies during emergencies caused by drought, contamination, or other disasters, funded through the Cleanup and Abatement Account.

fundingRange.notes: ≤$500K approved by Deputy/Executive Director; >$500K requires full Board approval; construction projects <$500K for small DACs

additionalCriteria: Must serve disadvantaged communities
Continuous basis — no deadlines
Reimbursement model (not advance funding)

programs.ragQuery: How does the Urgent Drinking Water Needs program work for emergency water supplies and what communities are eligible?

programs.name: Water Recycling Funding Program
programs.description: Promotes beneficial use of treated municipal wastewater to augment California's fresh water supplies through construction and planning grants for recycled water projects.

fundingRange.notes: FY 2025-26: $161.9M construction, $18.6M planning; max $15M construction / $300K planning per project

interestRate.notes: Construction grants (35% of cost); planning grants; CWSRF loan for remainder

additionalCriteria: Large-scale projects (10,000+ AFY) eligible for $15M per phase
Reduced match for disadvantaged communities
Continuous applications through FAAST

programs.ragQuery: What is the Water Recycling Funding Program and how do I apply for recycled water project grants?

programs.name: Water Storage Investment Program
programs.description: Largest Proposition 1 allocation ($2.7B) funding public benefit storage projects to add 2.5 million acre-feet of storage capacity, including Sites Reservoir and groundwater banking projects.

fundingRange.notes: $2.7B total; $2.646B committed; Sites Project $1.094B, Harvest Water $364.8M, Chino Basin $269.1M

additionalCriteria: Public benefit components only (not private benefit)
Eight active projects; no new solicitations

programs.ragQuery: What is the Water Storage Investment Program and what projects are being funded through Proposition 1?

programs.name: Clean Water State Revolving Fund
programs.description: Federal-state partnership providing low-interest financing for water quality projects including wastewater treatment, stormwater management, water recycling, and nonpoint source pollution control.

fundingRange.notes: No maximum per project; FY 2025-26 total fundable list ~$2.8B; loans ~$1.1B; principal forgiveness ~$514M

interestRate.notes: 50% of most recent GO Bond rate (Nov 2025: 2.2%); historical range 0.80%-3.00%

additionalCriteria: Priority scoring system (max 20 points; FY 2025-26 cutoff: 13 points)
Applications accepted continuously year-round

principalForgiveness.conditions: BIL General Supplemental: 49% as principal forgiveness; Emerging Contaminants: 100% principal forgiveness; Small community wastewater grants through CWSRF

programs.ragQuery: What are the CWSRF program details for wastewater, stormwater, and water recycling project financing?

programs.name: DWSRF Consolidation Incentive Program
programs.description: Financial incentives for receiving water systems that consolidate with smaller failing or at-risk systems, including zero-interest financing and per-connection grants.

fundingRange.notes: Zero-interest: up to $10M per consolidated community; grants: $3K-$10K per connection (max $1M); managerial consolidation: up to $2M at 0%

additionalCriteria: For receiving water systems consolidating with smaller systems
Grant amount per connection depends on DAC status of consolidated system
Physical or managerial consolidation eligible

principalForgiveness.conditions: Grant funding per connection: Non-DAC $3,000, Small DAC $5,000, Small SDAC $10,000 (max $1M per community)

programs.ragQuery: What financial incentives are available for water systems that consolidate with smaller systems?

programs.name: Drinking Water State Revolving Fund
programs.description: Provides affordable financing for drinking water infrastructure projects throughout California, including treatment, distribution, storage, consolidation, and source development.

fundingRange.notes: FY 2025-26 loan capacity $300M base program; ~$1B in grant/principal forgiveness available

interestRate.notes: 50% of state GO Bond rate; 0% for small SDAC systems; negative rates available for extreme hardship

additionalCriteria: Technical, Managerial, Financial (TMF) assessment required
Authorized Representative Resolution from governing body
Priority categories A-F based on health risk

principalForgiveness.conditions: Small DAC/SDAC: up to 100% of eligible cost ($80K-$120K per connection); Medium DAC: up to 50% ($5M max); Emerging contaminants: $25M per system

programs.ragQuery: What are the DWSRF eligibility requirements, interest rates, and principal forgiveness options for drinking water projects?

programs.name: Lead Service Line Replacement Program
programs.description: Federal Bipartisan Infrastructure Law funding for identification and full replacement of lead service lines, with priority to disadvantaged communities.

fundingRange.notes: California FY 2022: $250M; FY 2024-25: $28.7M (reduced due to incomplete inventory reporting)

interestRate.notes: 0% interest for non-DAC systems; principal forgiveness for DAC systems

additionalCriteria: 49% must be grants/forgivable loans to DACs
Inventory development and submission required

principalForgiveness.conditions: DAC systems: up to 100% principal forgiveness

programs.ragQuery: How can water systems access lead service line replacement funding through the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law?

programs.name: SAFER Direct Operations and Maintenance Funding
programs.description: Addresses affordability challenges for ongoing water system operations beyond capital infrastructure, providing direct O&M funding to small disadvantaged community water systems with high affordability burden.

fundingRange.notes: FY 2023-24 allocation: $18.7M for highest affordability burden systems

additionalCriteria: Group 1: Residential water rates >2.5% of community MHI
Group 2: Case-by-case for systems with existing debt burdens, K-12 school districts, tribal systems

programs.ragQuery: How does the SAFER operations and maintenance funding work for small disadvantaged water systems?

programs.name: Safe and Affordable Funding for Equity and Resilience
programs.description: Comprehensive program ensuring all Californians have access to safe and affordable drinking water through emergency response, technical assistance, consolidation support, operations and maintenance grants, and long-term infrastructure development.

fundingRange.notes: $130M annually through 2045 from Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund; additional $180M from Proposition 4; total distributed $1.6B+

interestRate.notes: Grant program — no repayment required for most DAC/SDAC projects

additionalCriteria: Priority given to systems on Failing or At-Risk list
Continuous year-round applications
Groundwater sustainability agencies also eligible

programs.ragQuery: What does the SAFER program cover and who is eligible for safe drinking water grants and emergency funding?

programs.name: Small Community Drinking Water Program
programs.description: Provides 0% interest financing and principal forgiveness for small disadvantaged community water systems needing treatment, distribution, consolidation, and source development projects.

fundingRange.notes: Principal forgiveness up to $80K-$120K per connection for DAC/SDAC

interestRate.notes: 0% interest available for eligible small community systems

additionalCriteria: Population ≤10,000 or ≤3,300 service connections
Continuous applications through FAAST

principalForgiveness.conditions: Available for small DAC/SDAC communities; up to 100% of eligible project cost

programs.ragQuery: What funding is available for small community drinking water systems under 10,000 population?

programs.name: California Rural Water Association
programs.description: State membership organization and primary training provider for small and rural water system operators, providing free on-site troubleshooting, leak detection, MHI studies, rate setting, GIS mapping, and certification preparation.

fundingRange.notes: Free TA services; training courses start at $20; also operates Rural Water Financing Agency for short-term construction loans

interestRate.notes: Rural Water Financing Agency offers fixed-rate interim and flex-term loans (separate from TA)

additionalCriteria: Small and rural water systems
Operator certification preparation and training
Advanced acoustic leak detection available

programs.ragQuery: What training and technical assistance does the California Rural Water Association provide?

programs.name: Community Water Center
programs.description: People of color-led nonprofit combining direct service delivery with community organizing and policy advocacy for water justice, serving San Joaquin Valley and Central Coast communities.

fundingRange.notes: No-cost services; helps communities access funding, organize collectively, and advocate for safe water

additionalCriteria: Focus: communities most impacted by drinking water crisis
Geographic: San Joaquin Valley and Central Coast (Monterey County)
Water justice framework — human right to water

programs.name: RCAC Tribal Circuit Rider Program
programs.description: Dedicated technical assistance for Indigenous communities with culturally appropriate services, routine training visits to tribal water systems, and support through Native American Water Master's Association.

programs.name: Rural Community Assistance Corporation
programs.description: Primary technical assistance and lending entity for rural and Indigenous communities in western states, providing project development, regulatory compliance, operations support, rate setting, and workforce development.

fundingRange.notes: Free TA services; also offers lending through Environmental Finance Center and Rooted Relative Fund for tribal enterprises

additionalCriteria: Small communities (<10,000 residents)

programs.name: Self-Help Enterprises Safe Drinking Water Program
programs.description: Technical assistance for 85+ small disadvantaged communities in California's San Joaquin Valley addressing contamination from arsenic, nitrates, uranium, pesticides, and bacteria.

fundingRange.notes: No-cost TA services; helps communities access SAFER, DWSRF, and DWR drought relief funding

additionalCriteria: Geographic focus: San Joaquin Valley, Tulare Lake Basin

programs.name: State Technical Assistance Funding Program
programs.description: Funds technical assistance for small disadvantaged communities including project coordination, engineering analysis, legal assistance, leak detection, compliance audits, financial analysis, and TMF assessments.

fundingRange.notes: Proposition 1 TA; SAFER TA allocation $20M FY 2024-25; demand significantly exceeds capacity

additionalCriteria: Priority: systems out of compliance, <200 connections

programs.name: USDA Rural Water Circuit Rider Program
programs.description: On-site, hands-on technical assistance to small rural water systems through experienced water utility professionals providing 24/7 support at no cost to systems.

fundingRange.notes: No-cost services; 132 circuit riders serving all 50 states

additionalCriteria: Water systems serving 10,000 or fewer people
